So your Cosen Tridewell may lawfully pursue his hopes in your Bride, whom he loues as eagerly as the melancholly virgine dotes on you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But may this hold good in Law Captaine?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There's a Ganon for it Sir. If both parties agree to a divorce after Marriage, so it be before Copulation.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Though the former part of his discourse, was a most egregious lye, yet the last hath some sound of pleasure in it: which I may make vse of.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Come gi'me the instrument. Shall I neuer find thee any where, but thou wilt by iust desert exact a beating from me? Hast thou no conscience? wouldst thou haue me lame my selfe, or melt my grease vpon thee. Come Sir, I haue ouer-heard you all; giue mee the Instrument, the instrument I say. Indeede I'le haue it. So. Now Sir—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay Cosen, for the seruice hee hath done you to night, and loue of mee, pardon him this time. Besides, his charge is in the house, at whose charge he liues. You will both shame and vndoe him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well Sir, I shall for this time pardon you, and neuer beat you more, it before Sir Phillip here you will subscribe to this. Tis nothing but a faithfull protestation to do reasonable things as I shall appoint, and not to reueale what I shall trust you withall.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If you will couenant on your part in defence of my reputation, to let me rayle at you behinde your backe, I will subscribe▪

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Take your pleasure. I am content. Write Sir.
In what without a Knaue we cannot end,
A Knaue imployd do's th' office of a frend.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Here Sir, I deliuer it as my deede.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here, and I deliuer you this againe to keepe. Indeed you shall for performance of couenants.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh Sir you are defeated. My sister hath fortified her lodging with locks, bolts, barres, and barricados.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To what end brother: for what cause?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I know not whither it be discontent or wilfulnesse, that possesses her: but you are to haue no entrance there to night. That she has sufficiently sworne.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! am I denied? To my wish.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Pray let me speake with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: At large you shall. For though it bee my wedding night you shall be my Bedfellow. Lights there. Good night brother.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good night Captaine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now Gouernour? what has angerd thee? something troubles thy countenance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Your comming, and the priviledge of this place hath once more preseru'd that vnworthy Tridewell from the justice of my fury, which should haue fallen on him, had he bin twind with me by this light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By this light, Gouernour? would you haue fought by Candle-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir I dare do't by day light, Moone-light, Star-light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ow'e-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Any light vnder the Sunne. And that shall bee tride well on Tridewell head, dec heare?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A good iest! Tride well vpon Tridewell. He has wit in his anger. But Gouernour, laying your anger aside, let me be beholden to your wit in atchieuing this Northern Lasse. Thy acquaintance with her must be the meanes. Prithee goe lye with me, and helpe mee to dreame out some course. Nay looke now thy furie blowes so high thou dost not heare me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Not heare? yet, were I in a Combat as great as euer I my selfe fought any, I could both heare, and giue counsell. Therefore say vnto your selfe, by the helpe of your
Gouernour shee is your owne.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O Man past example!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But dee heare?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here, here. Thou shalt haue anything—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Come your wayes huswife. No more of your whynings, and counterfet tricks. If this Gentleman be not worthy of your loue, I am not worthy to be your Vncle, directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Alas, what meane you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Accept of him, you accept of me. if you refuse him you deny me directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee vnderstands you not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: If you will ioyne hands and faith with him, Here's your portion, there's your ioincture; if not, your way lies before you, pack directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Good sir, consider her disease. If her vnderstanding were direct, you might speake directly to her. But if I haue any discretion shee is too full of melancholly to be purg'd this way.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What would you haue me doe? Or how in your discretion would you councell me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Not to be mad sir, because shee is melancholly, not by taking a wrong course for her recouery to ruine her, and forfeit your iudgement Doe you thinke, that commands with chidings, threats, or stripes haue power to worke vpon her, when shee has neither will nor reason within her selfe to doe, or not to doe anything whatsoeuer.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now the g●gs vp.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If her health in sense and vnderstanding were perfect: yet as shee is Woman, her will were first to be wrought vpon by faire and gentle treaty. But as shee is at this time so sicke in mind, that knowledge of what shee is, what shee do●, especially of what shee should doe is dead in her, her Mind must bee first recouer'd; and that by a due course, in soft and temperate proceedings; to which fit time as well as meanes must bee allowed. Moreouer—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Oh. No moreouers I beseech you, not more of her at this time. I vnderstand your purpose already. I doe directly. Therefore speedily take what course, and vse what meanes shall in your discretion be thought fit. I will subcribe, I will directly subscribe to your discretion. My wife when shee went out of the worlde left me as great a care behind her in the charge she gaue me with this Woman, this quick sighted Guide of my house, a blind one were better.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You should first see, if it pleased you, how her affection may bee wrought vpon by the Gentlemans owne faire intreaty. Pray sir speake to her like a Suter, looke vpon him Sweet heart: This Gentleman loues you. Pray speake sir. Doe you not?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Neuer credit me pretty Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor will I, feare it not. Nor any man that sayes hee loues me. For alas! I was too lately scorn'd.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: You are a Lasse indeed. I protest and vow, and such ●●ne, as I would bee very sorry to appeare any way, or in the least decree, as it were please you to vnderstand me: for Ile be sworne, ●he●e is not in the World.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Truth in swearing, lesse in promising.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If you will beleeue me Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor ne man for your sake.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world I say—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I say so too sir. What wast I pray.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world any Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tell that no further; for wee are all too gentle lessen men were lesse cruell.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Heare him speake Constance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You shall heare me sing first by your leaue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Poore heart.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here's wise worke! direct lunacy and Ideotisme. Blesse my house from the Ward Masters Informers,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray sir, are you sir Phillip?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Say you are.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Yes Lady, I am sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But you are none of my Sparrow. Your mouth's not wide enough for your words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee has stop'd his mouth there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: His words would soften Adamantine eares. And lookes would melt a Marble heart to teares. O Wea is me!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay you must not weepe Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 I doe them? Shall I euer get him by singing trou yee? Introth I would neuer but sing, if I thought that were the gainest way.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I had rather heare you sing though, then see you weep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It must bee of my Loue than, my Sparrow as I told you. And thus it goes.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: A bonny bonny Bird I had
A bird that was my Marroe:
A bird whose pastime made me glad,
And Phillip twas my Sparrow.
A pretty play-fere: Chirp it would,
And hop, and fly to fist,
Keepe cut, as ● were a Vsurers Gold,
And bill me when I list.
Phillip, Phillip, Phillip it cryes
But hee is fled and my loy dyes.
But were my Phillip comd a gaine,
I would not change my Loue
For Iuno's bird with gawdy traine,
Nor yet for Venus Doue.
Nay, would my Phillip come againe,
I would not change my state,
For his great Name sakes wealth of Spaine,
To be anothers Mate.
Phillip Phillip, &c.

sp.p: No no, you cannot be the Man. I know him right weel by you sir, as wily as you be. Gin you had all his trim geere vpon you, and all his sweets about you, yet I should not bee so fond to mistake a Ienny How let for a Tassell Gentle. Ah, ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why Lone, what fault doe you find in this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Feath, but eene eane. That her is not Sir Phillip. For thus would hee doe. Thus would hee kisse his hand; and thus ta' me by mine. Thus would hee looke, and set his eye on mine: And giue mee leaue to see my selfe in's eyes. Twas the
best Glasse introth that ere I saw. I nere looke weell fine. Nor ere shall ime sure, vntill I see me there againe.
sp.l: But hee is geaue, alas hee's geane, and all too late I sorow.
For I shall neuer bee well againe, till yesterday be to marow.
sp.p: God you good Euen sir.—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: ●ollow her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And put her to't sir, and out of this humor. Ile add the tother fiue hundred to her portion, and you bring her about handsomely. O when I was a Batchelor! I thinke I can doe somewhat yet in my old dayes. But when I was a Batchelor, how I could haue handled this geere.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Neuer credit me sir, if you will beleeue me but—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I doe beleeue you sir suficiently good Master Nonsense. No more of your impertinent speeches. But follow her, and put her to't I say, to't directly. Take her into the Orchard twas there shee fell in loue they say It may bee the place is O neno ●.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, there will bee no way for her recouery, but to remou. her lodging, and haue some good Phisicians about her.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where you please; and vse whose helpe you please: shee is your owne; dispose of her freely, as I will of what is 〈…〉 course of life directly. Let me see. Shee is lost, past recouery. Say I should marry, I might yet haue an 〈…〉 mine owne.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, but of whose getting sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There might rise a fearefull question.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Thinke not of it sir. A man of your yeares, and grauity, with the respect the World giues you for your place and worship in the Common Wealth, together with the riches you haue pild vp in a Mountainous estate; to cast all downe with your selfe, and fortune at the foot of a stranger I Thinke what would be thought of you, if such a dotage should possesse you

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Shee's falling into a tedious Lecture.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray how was Master Spartledirt talk'd on tother day for doing such a tricke? yet he was held a wise Lawyer: You see a faire example in the late Mariage of sir Phillip Lucklesse, and his Fitchow, a Match of your owne making, and cause of your Neeces and your owne Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: There's tugging for a Mastery, and buffetting for the breeches. He barks at her, shee snaps at him; shee breaks his wine Glasse, hee her looking Glasse; shee puts away his Seruants, hee turnes away hers; shee locks her Chamber dore, he bolts his, begetting nothing but a World of strife and disorder.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray shut vp that point, I will not marry. No directly I will not, though the truth is my purpose: was to haue cast my selfe and fortune wholly vpon you, if it might houe seem'd well in your discretion, vmh vmh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I pray stay a little sir, take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not a step further, this way by your leaue. I thinke I haue pusseld her discretion.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Vnderstand me sir. As I would not haue you fall rashly vpon anything; no more would I haue you flie sodainly from any purpose, without advise and sober deliberation. If you should marry one that would be a Comfortable Nurse vnto you, as (though I say'●) you partly know—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Say you nothing, ●er I doe know nothing, nor I will know nothing more of this matter directly: For if euer I marry, let me suffer all that the-Law prouides for Periury; let me bee cropt and slitt worse then a French Curtall, or a parliamentall delinquent for blaspheming the blood royall. No, I wil now bestow my wealth in Monumentall good deedes, and charitable vses in my life time, to bee talkd well on when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, build Almes houses and Hospitals for beggers, and prouide in Bridewell, and houses of Correction for your frends and kindred. Pray giue enough to Bedlem, you may feele some part of that benefit your selfe before you die, if these sits hold you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Shee would haue me doe no good with that I haue neither. Let mee consider. The most I haue to say directly hath not beene very well gotten. Were it not a point of good conscience, to spend that prodigally, and saue a 〈…〉 And that which I haue got well and honestly, hath beene with much care and trauell; were it not then a point of equity to my selfe, to spend that with ease and pleasure? Tis done directly, what I haue is mine owne; and I will be merry with it. Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What's the toy now?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirah. Take there twenty peeces. B stow it all presently in choycest meates, and richest Wines for my Supper. This one nights Supper directly. What I haue is mine owne: and I will be merry with it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Cl●. Blesse vs!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Six brace of Partriches, and sixe Pheasants in a Dish. Godwits, Knots, Quailes, and the rest of the meares answerable for halfe a score, or a dosen persons of the best quality: whom I will thinke of presently.

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.p: Braine of a downe right Iustice! What meanes my Master, to leape out of thirtie shillings a Weeke house keeping into twentie pounds a Supper? I may sell my Clearks place: for sure he meanes to thrust himselfe out of the Commission. Hee can be no Iustice long if this humor hold. Who shall be the Guests tro●?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I haue it directly. You shall goe to the Ordinaries, and from thence inuite such young Gallants as you find to be Gamesters. I meane of the highest cut.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Men that you doe not know sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I directly. If they know me, or haue heard of me tis sufficient: we shall be soone acquainted. Bring not a man with any paid for gold Lase or Scarlet about him, I charge you, nor without a Protection in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You run a great hazard in this sir. You may perhaps be cheated of all you haue, if I haue any discreation.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And much good do't their good hearts. What I haue is mine owne, and I will bee merry with it directly. You haue put me by one or two courses: But not all your discretion shall beat me out of this. If you take some care in the busines, and huswife the intertainement to make it braue for my credit, you may get a Gowne or a Iewell by it. If not—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir ile obey you. If he bee mad I will not bee foolish, bat strike in for a ●●are. And for your Guests sir, let me alone. My man is best acquainted at the Ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Why now you speake.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Within there. Beauis. But introth sir, I doubt whither any such Guests will come, you haue alwayes beene so strict and terrible in your iustitiary courses.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Let him say mine eyes are opened, and their vertue is reuealed
vnto me. And if any of the youngsters haue Mistrisses, let 'hem bring'hem. They shall haue Mn●cke● what I haue is mine owne, and I will be merry with it. My flesh, though not in the way of mariage, requires some satisfaction too. Where might a man in all this plentifull Towne, find a choyce peece directly that he might make his owne? only his owne? A very hard question. And custome has made it almost an vnreasonable, though it were in ones owne Wife. In a Cittizens or Tradesmans Wife; a Man must suffer the Riuall-ship of a slouenly husband: the stinke of his hornes euer vnder ones nose. A cast Lady, or Gentlewoman of courtly acquaintance, to maintaine her, is to feed a Fountaine, that wasts it selfe through many Spowts: What I supply her with, will be drawne out by twenty. All her friends must share of my prodigality. To traine vp an innocent countrey Girle, is like hatching a Cuckoe; as soone as shee is ripe, and sees the world afore her, shee flies at her aduantage, and leaues mee dead i'the neast. How now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Delinquent brought before your worship to be examined, a Gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Who brings her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Vexhem the Constable sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Looke on his feet. Sure tis the Diuell in his likenesse: That old Bawd knowing how it stood with me, has brought me one of his Succubae Art. Sure tis Vexhem?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sure sir? The diuell himselfe knowes him not better then I know him from the Diuell. I am sure, hee has beene in see with me these nine yeares: almost euer since hee was Constable; and has brought more profit to my deske then all the honest Officers in the counties of your Commission sir. Oh hee's a rare fellow, hee'll tickle a Whore in Coany.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You know my mind. I will in and handle this geere in priuity.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Beauis, You vnderstand me. Prithee goe discreetly about it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray let me see a little of this first.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If I put her to't or euer offer to put any Woman to't againe, neuer credit me: let me neuer be trusted, I protest and 〈◊〉 Gentlewoman shee has vs'd me—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Very ill fauouredly me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Ha' you put her to't sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I cannot put her to't, nor she will not be put to't. Sing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I wo'not goe to't, nor I man not goe to't,
For loue, nor yet for see:
For I am a Mayd, and will be a Mayd,
And a good one till I dye.
Yet mine intent, I could repent, for ●ne mane company.
sp.p: But you are not he Sir. If you be, you are wondrously chang'd. I am sure his faults were not written on his forehead. God pardon him.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If mine bee, you can best read'hem, t'is your owne hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Shee has done a cure on him. Hee spoke sense now. Alas Sir, that a faire hand should make such blots I what hand is it? Secretar, Romane, Court, or Text? I haue not seene the like: 'tis all dominicall letters, red Inke. His face is like an Almanack of all Holy dayes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sure tis Stenography, every Character a word: and here and there one for a whole sentence.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here's one might serue for a whole History. The life and death o' 'Raw head, and Bloody bones.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I see I am not such an Asse, I would I might neuer stir but I am— Where's Sir Paull If I doe not tell him—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What did you to provoke her thus?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Nothing but what I can answere in a sort dee see me as well as— neuer gi'me credit I had warrant vnder his hand

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Now
sp.p: By word of mouth sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: That's about hand by your leaue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Is it so? Good Sir, his meaning was, you should put her fairely on like a Louer, with sweet speeches, and gentle behaviour.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Shee vnderstands nothing that I can speake.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Nor any body else I thinke.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And therefore you fell to expresse your selfe in rude action. Shee has scorn'd you but well: you are a fine putter to't indeede.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Mum toot Mun toot, Muntara rara Muntara ra ra rarie,
And euer I sigh and cray alack for Phillips loue I die.

iust so did our Deyry Mayd at home serue my Lady Fidledees Batler. And there I learnt it. But when shee had so done what did shee than doe? Bestow'd a penyworth of Vnguentum Album, and it made him whole presently. Good Mrs. Traynwell send to your Pothecary for some: 'twill make him wee ● e'now now.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: I sweet-heart: but first you shall goe in the Coach with●● to the Doctors.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: I know I am not weell too. But Ile ha'no Doctor but Sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: It shall be Sir Phillip, (poore soule,) all must be Sir Phillip. You shall lye at his house.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But not with him by my faith, and your leaue, in't wee be married. Prithee Beauis gar him wash his face hee'll scare some bodies Barnes else.—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Ile throw him into the Dock rather then he shall succeede Iack O'Dandy. Come sir, all shal be wel again. Feare not.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

div.head: Act. III. Sce. III.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cosen, I vnderstand you at full. And am glad that occasion hath pointed out a probability to lead me out of this labirinth; and you to your desired end.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Follow but the way you are in Sir, and you shall arriue at your owne wishes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shee has put me into't her selfe too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: By sequestring her selfe from you the first night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For which Cosen, if I take not occasion to keepe my selfe from her, all nights, dayes, and times hereafter, may the act of our bodies beget prodigeous monsters and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A fearefull vow! looke too't. And I warrant shee sues for the Divorce first.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
May wee proue but as certaine as you are confident in out other proiect, for recalling Constance to her selfe, and mee
then to her, these fetters being shaken off, may they proue golden ones to you, I shall not envie you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For her take no thought sir. The intrest I haue in her Tutresse, with the work I haue fashion'd vpon my Anvil, shall bring all to your wish. I expect to heare from him instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile freely resigne your wish to you, and adde halfe I haue to augment her estate to you. Oh I tremble to thinke on her: her presence shakes the house like an earthquake: the outrage of Prentizes is not so terrible to a Bawd or a Cutpurse, as her voyce is to me. Yet to you shee may be calme as the breath of friendship, and milde as the midnight whispers of chast loue.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir, I professe my affection flies eagerly at her. Shee takes me deepely, how euer you haue mistaken one another. Oh here comes my Anvile! Mee thinkes his very countenance invites me to strike him▪ though I know hee dos me good service now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Tis done sir. I warrant shee's plac'd, succesfully, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I haue sent her before his Worship by a Constable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who has he sent? before whose Worship?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You shall know all. He has sent your cast whore before sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Mistery, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: The successe shall vnfold it in good time to your and my benefit? doubt not, if she but follow her instructions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, if shee be not Mistris of her Art, there is no deceit among Trades men, no bribery among Officers, no bankrupt out of Ludgate, nor Whore out of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And if I ha' not fitted her with a Second, my friend vex him, the Constable, then say there is no wit among Knaues, no want among Schollers, no rest in the graue, nor vnquietnesse in Mariage, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Of which here comes the truest testimony.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out of my doores thou Miscreant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay sister. O governour, art here.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Avoyd my house, and that presently, Ile claw your skin
off after your Liuory else, and make you so much nakeder then time makes all other seruing Creatures.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe you talke of turning away my Man? You shall give me leaue to turne away your Howdee first, and then put off my, God a mercy how dost thou.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I ieerd? flowted to my face? Is this fit vsage for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Wife? a Witch.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A Husband? a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Lux
sp.p: Out pusse.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Nay sir, indeed the fault is yours most extreamly now. Pray sir forbeare to straine beyond a Womans patience.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I scornd and reuild?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Made a property for laughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Haue I no friend, no Seruant to command?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Has my Ladiship made me so lamentable a thing, that I haue lost the power of a Mistris? You sir, run and call some frends to succour me, or Ile thratle you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stirre but a foot sirah, or vtter but a sillable, and ile cut your thratle pipe.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I shall be caru'd out betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What will become of me? you, Wood-cock, Ninihammer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Haue you forgot my name sister? would not Widgine become your mouth, as wel? forget your natural brothers name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Can you call me sister, and see me abus'd thus?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Foutre for sisters; I am not to medle with an other mans Wife. I am about one for my selfe. You mention'd her first to me. But I must be be holden to others wits and meanes to compasse her: or else—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe as I bid you, or—

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O sir shee'll rend me in peeces, teare me like a Larke.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dost thou feare her or me. Do't or I—

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, there's Master Walter can sing it rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he shall sir, and so will all; but you must put vs in. Beginne.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hey downe downe, &c.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister, Wife, and all, is a present nothing to this. Come round Gentlemen▪ Keepe her but off, and let me alone.

div.p: They all take hands, and dance round. Widgine in the midst sings this Song. They all beare the burden, while shee scolds and striues to be amongst'hem. Tridewell holds her off.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Hee that marries a Scold, a Scold,
Hee has most cause to be merry:
For when shee's in her fits, he may cherish his wits
By singing hey downe derry.

sp.speaker: A●l.
sp.p: — Hey downe downe derry downe downe downe, &c.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Gallants. I apprehend you would bee priuate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O no Master Bulfinch, you shall make one of our Councill.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I apprehend Gentlemen you are merrily dispos'd; in good sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Apprehend a fooles head. Come into play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I, 〈◊〉 with him, and about againe.

div.stage: They pull him into the Round.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that marries a merry Lasse,
He has most cause to be ●ad;
For let her goe free in her merry tricks, shee
Will worke his Patience mad.
But he that marries a Scold a Scold, &c.
He that weds with a Roaring Girle,
that will both scratch and bite▪
Though he study all day to make her away,
will be glad to please her at night.
And he that copes with a sullen Wench,
That scarce will speake at all,
Her doggednesse more then a Scold or a Whore,
Will perpetrate his Gall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hey downe downe, &c.
He that's matchd with a Turtle Doue,
That has no spleene about her,
Shall wast so much life in the loue of his wife,
He were better be without her.
But hee that marries a Scold, a Scold, &c.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O scorne vpon scorne, torment vpon torment. Let me rather be buried aliue then beare this. 〈◊〉 Shee gets loose. Slaues, Rascals, get yee all out of my doores. By vertue of my nayles, I charge yee. ●e not leaue an Eye or a Nose amongst yee

sp.speaker: How. Wid. Bull. Anv.
sp.l: O Lord, O Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come bouncing after my boyes.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.l: Oh how am I wrong'd.

div.stage: Ex. Omnes preter Fit. Tri. Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Sure I did apprehend this mirth as ●ight as could bee possible the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Madame, I see too much of your vexation; and indeed I suffer too much with you. As I am a Gentleman I will giue you right frendly Councill, if you will heare me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir I haue perceiu'd humanity in you and doe loue it in you. But I know not what to doe, nor whom to heare. I am fallen into the pit of bondage, and will take any course for my Redemption. Oh Master Bulfinch.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This will make to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Sir I am wrongd beyond expression. This Gentleman is an eye witnes of my suffrings. Pray come in Sir. I will heare your counsell together with this Gentlemans aduise.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madame, your case is in my apprehension, most desperate, yet 〈…〉 comfort in regard you seeke aduise and counsell. Mine is euer ready, and more fortunate oftentimes the Iudicious. For I doe nothing but vpon good reason and deliberation.

div.trailer: The end of the third Act.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir I beseech your worship, deale not so seuerely with mee.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirah I will teach you how to deale with Dealers, and not with vertuous Gentlewomen; bring Innocency before Iustice; and be able to lay nothing to her charge.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Indeed sir, the Captaine inform'd me of her; and said he would be here ready to accuse her. Good sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most officious Sir. What warrant had you? None. What is the Captaines name? you know not. Where's his lodgeing? you are ignorant. But here was your cunning; it appeares most plainely, that you thinking her to bee one of the trade, thought to make a Prey of her purse: which since your affrightment, could not make her open vnto you, you thought to make her Innocency smart for't. I will make your Knauery smart for't directly. Come is the Mittimus ready? gi' mee't—

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Good your worship, hold your hand. For my poore familie sake.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here take him forth, and let the next Constable conuey him to Nowgate.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir 'tis the first time that euer I offended in this kind. I pray your worship be of a better mind towards me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Away I say directly. As I am in my right Mind and Midlesex. I will shew my iustice on thee.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Do's the Knaue laugh? Bring him backe. May a man aske the cause of your Mirth? Vex. Sir I haue laught at the vexation of a thousand in my dayes. I hope I may haue leaue once in my life to laugh at mine owne.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Oh is it so? Pray hold you merry sir.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Lady, whereas you were brought before me as a Delinquent, I retaine you as my Mistris. I like her beyond measure. A pretty young thing: new brought to a pace! Ah, h●! Shee has committed a little Countrey folly, as shee priuately confesses. Whats that ● It may stand in ranke with that they call vertue here; and then shee is content to liue as priuately as I please. Shee shall vp, I will winter and sommer her before shee shall see a high way of this Towne. Shee's for my turne directly. Mistris Holdup, is your name say you?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Camitha Holdup sir. A poore Gentlewoman. My father
bore the office of a Commissioner for the peace in the West countrey, till Misfortune wrought his estate out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Holdup! I haue heard of him, and know what twas that sunke him. Hee liu'd by the Sea side; twas trading with the Pirats. Buying their goods, and selling them victuals;

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Tis too true sir. He paid so dearely for't at last, that I haue no more, but my bare breeding, and what I beare about me to liue vpon.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Which is enough ● enough directly; if you can beare your selfe discreetly, and containe your selfe within those bounds of Fortune, in which Ile plant you. Alas good soule, weepe not; let Money and Authority bee thy comfort. By which thou shalt feele no want, nor feare no danger. But to our busines. I haue already acquainted you with my Neece Constances disease, and that shee is remou'd out of my house for her health. I will lodge you at a trusty Tenants house where she is vnknowen. You shall take her name vpon you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Which is mine owne already.

sp.speaker: Seu
sp.p: And if you can but a little counterfet her Melancholly, you may freely passe for her; and my accesses to thee, my sweet Girle, shall crowne vs with fulnes of delight and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, you haue most worthily made me your owne; and all my study shall be to obey you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now had I but ● fit attendant for the person of my loue▪

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Some simple honest body sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Then we were fitted. How now.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: My Lady Lucklesse man desire to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Stand you by vnseene a while. Send him in. I doe expect some Message now, in the behalfe of her vnlucky Ladyships wise brother, Master Widgine, touching my Neece. Now stend how do's my good Lady?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I left her very ill sir; for she has beaten me, and thrust me out of doores with her owne hands, without penny in my purse, or other Cloake o'my back, then the bare Liuory, that a cast Seruing man can not shake off, of Knave and Beggar.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou leftest her very ill indeed. But well, thou wouldst haue me bee a meanes to reestablish thee in thy Lady.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In her seruice sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I speake by a figure Humfrey: for to be inward with, or indeed within a Mistris, is to be a service in the most Courtly phrase.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I sir. Those are conuenient Seruants sir. Wee are couenant seruants. They are respected aboue husbands: Wee abased beneath slaues. They purchase place, honors, and offices oftentimes with their Ladies 〈…〉, when wee finde not our wages without hard words, and are in feare, (poore snakes) to haue our sloughes pulled ouer our eares before the yeare goe about. Wee drudge for our Ladies, they play with their Ladies: But the best is, wee labour and sweat it out for our Ladies, when they are faine to talke Physick, and lye in for their Ladies.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most intelligent Humfrey. Let vs retire to the purpose. Put case I haue a Mistris in store for you; to whom I may commend you vpon my owne credit, and vndertake for your entertainment and meanes by my owne purse. What would you say? what would you doe?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, I will say ouer the Gent. vshers Grammar to you, and doe her seruice by the rules.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said directly. Incipe Humfride. Say your part.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In a Gentleman Vsher there be eight parts. Boldnesse, Neatnesse, Flattery and Secresie, rewarded. Diligence, Obedience Truth and Honesty, vnrewarded.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What is his Boldnesse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: His Boldnesse is the vse of his Manhood in right of his Ladies honour, degree, place or priuiledge, at home, abroad, in priuate or publique meeting, for the hand, for the w●ll, for the what she will, for the what she calls.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How is it rewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: By obtaining of Sutes made out of cast Gownes or Petticoates. Which if hee be a Taylor, as most of our middle sort of Professours are, hee is thereby made a Man in spight of the prouerbe, and thrust into the high way of aduancement.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Perge Humfrey His neatnesse now?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p:
His neatnesse consists most diuersly▪ sir. Not onely in the decent wearing of those cloathes and cleane linnen, pruning his haire, russling his Bootes, or ordring his shooes tyes; these are poore expressions, a iouney man Barbar will doo't. But to
doe his office neatly, his garbe, his pace, his postures, his co●es on and his comes off, complements, his visites 〈◊〉▪

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: His Howdees.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In which a profound iudgement could be pusselled.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I beleeue thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: And the most absolute or artificiall memory set o'the rack. To be able to relate how this Ladies tooth does; and tother Ladies toe. How this Ladies Milk does: and how tothers Doctor lik'd her last water: how this Ladies husband; and how tother Ladies dogge slept last night: how this childe, that Monkey, this Nurse, that Parrat, and a thousand such. Then his neatnesse in Chamber-worke, or about the person of his Lady, in case her Mayd or her Woman be otherwise occupied, to conuey a pin into her ruffe neatly, or adde a help to her head dressing, as well as Iohn among the Maydes, Lastly, his dexterity in Caruing, and his discretion in Marshalling of meates; to giue euery messe the due seruice, and euery dish his lawfull preheminence.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And how is this neatnesse rewarded Humfrey?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Doubly sir: at boord and at bed▪ by good bits, and the loue of the Chambermayd.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well Humfrey, because wee will not make this scene too long, we will omit the rest: onely why are your last foure parts, Diligence, Obedience, Truth and Honesty vnrewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir. They are parts that spring out of vertue, and are therefore borne with their reward in their mouthes, and ought to expect no further from any seruice in these times.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most edifying Humfrey. I haue a Mistris in store for thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I long to see her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Didst thou never see my Neece Constance?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: No sir. But I haue heard shee is diseas'd with Melancholly; and if she should proue mad too, like my old Lady, I were then as farre to seeke as ere I was.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Feare it not Humfrey. My 〈◊〉 ease thy care. Neece come forth. [Enter Holdup. ]I shall fit you with a seruant. Fall to your Postures Humfrey. Your Garbe. [He does his postures ]So. Your Pace. So. Your Congie. So. Hand your Lady. Good. Arme your Lady. Good still. Side your Lady. Very good. Draw out your Lady. Excellent. Present
your Lady. Singular well, good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, I can Shoulder my Lady too: but that is when she takes Coach; and Foot my Lady, when she alights.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Precious Humfrey, I admire thy Art.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I learnt all of a good old Ladies man in the Strand sir, that must be namelesse.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Humfrey, Walke your Lady to the Burse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O most Hostlerly spoken! Vnder correction sir, Wayt your Lady I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said Humfrey. Here's something for my instruction. Now wayt your Lady to the Burse. She has some trifles to buy there. I will finde you there presently, and conduct you to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: What shall I doe with all this sir? I would indeed but buy an ounce or two of threed; some Netting pins and Needles, and a Frame to flourish my worke on. Hereafter I will worke in gold and siluer, if you please, for your owne wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: As I would wish! her simplicity takes mee aboue her beauty. Goe I say. I'le follow. Mee thinkes I eene feele my selfe, thanke my selfe for being in this good humour. What I haue is mine owne, and I will be merry with it directly.—

div.head: Act. IIII. Sce. II.
div.stage: Enter Fitchow, Tridewell, Bulfinch, Widgine, Anuile.

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you now know the calamity I suffer vnder. And you haue shew'd mee the best way to comfort: for which I thanke you. I haue giuen you my resolution for a Divorce, vpon condition. Before which, I must promise you nothing sir. But I assure you in the meane time, you stand prime in my affection: for I haue in all found you a right worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madame, I haue not vtterance to declare my acceptance of your loue. It must therefore be lock'd vp in my breast, the treasure of my heart. Now for the condition vpon which your Divorce depends, we must see that perform'd, and then—

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Sir, I will make good more then I now may promise.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You speake nobly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It relishes a little ● do much of womanly wilfulnesse I confesse. But all my wilfulnesse (that I'le promise you sir) shall die in the end of this businesse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well then, before your discreet neighbour M. Bulfinch here. If you haue not your will in this, I will disclaime in your favour hereafter. Sir, the condition is (as you may remember—

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend it Sir. That sir Paul Squelch his Neece be first married or contracted, and then she consents to a divorce: And that you be assistant to her brother here to obtaine her for him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: To which I promise my ready helpe, onely I must not appeare in the businesse.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I will onely appeare in it, for I will not be seene in the matter.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As thus sir. I will keepe your counsell: not onely in holding my peace to all the world, but in saying nothing to sir Paul himselfe. Dee apprehend me sir?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And thanke you sir. Now every man to his part M. Widgine, You haue both your sisters and my best directions already, which I doubt not but with the helpe of your Governor you will make good vse of. Madame will you in, and but wish well to our proceedings, and trouble your thoughts no further.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, what helpe he has of me, is for the Ladies and his owne sake, not your's dee heare.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No blustring now good Governour: Prithee restraine thy fury. Thou canst never heare nor speak to that Gent. with any patience; and yet he is on our side now. Prithee let's loose no time. I never long'd more for my mothers comming from a Christning, then to be at this Northern Lasse.—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Wanton, you haue begun propitiously: Proceede but confidently, and I'le warrant thee a wealthy husband by it, or a composition that may proue the better purchase.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir, be you and this Lady but as confident of my fidelity,
and trust me in this action, and if I breake not the toyles your Kinsman is in, and make you Mistris of my Intrest in sir Paul, let all the good you intended me, bee a lockram Coife, a blew Gowne, a Wheele and a cleane Whip. You are sure the Lady will yeild to Diuorce, if Constance whom I now personate be first maried or contracted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Right. Shee do's but hold off till then, and that wilfully; because shee feares it is for Constances loue onely, that her Husband desires the Divorce.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And you are sure that Constance is safe from her discouery.

sp.speaker: Try
sp.p: I vpon the hazard of my discretion.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: To any then that knowes her not very well, If I appeare not the same Constance— you haue giuen me her Character right?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: The best that we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, I haue a further helpe then, you both imagine yet.

sp.speaker: Tri. Tra.
sp.p: May wee know it.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: It shall be no secret. My Seruant Howdee, whom you and sir Paul, suppose his Lady turn'd away, was by her Ladiship taught onely to faigne it; and cunningly instructed to worke himselfe into the seruice of Constance, to further her brothers proceedings. And since fortune has put him vpon me, whom hee takes to bee the same Mistris, if I make not apt vse of it—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Tis most fairely omenous. Come Lady. Hee cannot. but bee at hand; and our stay may doe hurt, (You remember the Doctors lodging I told you of, and sir Phillips appointment to meet you there an houre hence?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: All sir. I would vse no other. She is there already. Ex.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No more then; away. Fare you well sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
If my deceit now, should bee discouered, before my worke be ended, my Brain tricks might perhaps, in stead of all these faire hopes, Purchase me the Lash. fore Venus. my flesh eene trembles to thinke on't. It brings likewise into my consideration, the basenesse of my condition; how much vnpittied the punishment of a Whore is, and how sodainely it ouertakes her? My ioynt Conspiratours are in no danger. I only run the
hazard, though they are as deepe in fact as my selfe. Well. If I scape this pull, and draw any fortune by't, Ile change my function sure. A common Whore? Ile be a Nun rather. They come most fitly, and I must into my fit— Withdrawes behind the hanging.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Indeed sir, it was my Ladies plot, but you must take no notice of it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile thanke her with all my heart, and shee shall neuer know on't.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But if sir Paul, my now Master should discouer my deceit, how shall I scape his vengeance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What dost thou thinke of me, weake fellow? Am not I a Commander, ha?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I, in the warre Captaine: but hee is a Iustice of Peace, and a Commander of Captaines in Midlesex, sends two or three drunken Ones to Newgate at a clap sometimes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Feare no discouery Humfrey. Let me but see her, and Ile warrant thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee'll see none but sir Phillip, you must be no body else. Remember that: you must know no other name you haue. Now if you can sir Phillip it handsomely there's it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant thee, and my Gouernour shall sir Phillip me at euery word; and if I doe not sir Phillip her, better then euer shee was Phillips in her life, then say I am no Legitimate Widgine.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: ●is pa●● your strength or reach either by forty I beleeue. I doubt your midle finger is too short Master Widgine.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Well, I must venter it. Here shee comes. Has a Baby.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's shee doing. Ods me ● making a Baby I thinke Are you good at that ifaith? Ile be at that sport with you, it shall cost me a fall else.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Oh shee has a hundred such ● pish toyes. E●ne now shee was great with Child forsooth as shee could goe. And was perswaded she had a Child as big as I in her belly. I wondred at it, and shee told me shee had had a hundred there as big in her dayes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I but shee knew not what shee said. By and by, I must be a Man-Midwife forsooth and deliuer her: for twas past all Womans skill? Now shee thinkes shee is brought a bed, and nurses the Child her selfe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And who's the father?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O none but sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile father it as well as hee. Ist a Boy or a Girle trow▪ Would shee would make a Christning Banquet while wee are here. Harke shee sings.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Peace wayward Barne; O cease thy mo●e:
Thy farre more wayward Daddy's gone:
And neuer will recalled be
By cryes of either thee, or me:
For should wee cry,
vntill wee dye,
Wee could not scent his cruelty.
Ballow, Ballow, &c.
Hee needs might in himselfe foresee,
What thou successiuely might'st be;
And could hee then, (though me foregoe)
His Infant leaue, ere hee did know,
How like the Dad
would bee the Lad,
In time, to make fond Maydens glad
Ballow, ballew, &c.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is this pretty Mrs. Constance, that you complaine of your Loue before he be lost?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Who be you I pray?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray thee tell her Gouernour. I ha'not the heart to lye now.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: It is sir Phillip Lady, come to doe you right. De● heare?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes sir, I heare you vary weell; and could eene wish i' my heart I could beleeue you.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Speake your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You may Mistris Constance; for as I am an honest man,
I neuer meant to wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I doe beleeue you sir. But pray protest no more by that name till you make your selfe such by marying me. You haue getten a barne by me, I is sure o'that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I come for the same purpose Sweet-heart. Ile both father and keepe thy Child, and make thee an honest Woman. Giue mee your hand before this Gentleman, and your Seruant here; and say but the word; Ile get a Licence presently, fetch you away, and dispatch you to night.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Marry mee, marry me, quoth the bonny Lasse: and when will you beginne.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As for thy wedding Lasse wee'll doe well enough, in spight ● 'the best o' thy Kinne.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I can but thanke you, obey you, and pray for you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gouernour; wilt thou beleeue me? It eene pitties my heart, to wrong so sweet a peece of simplicity. But Fortune has drest her for me to seed on; and Ile fall to.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Or the Deuill to choake you. Well boystrous Master Tridewell, your Ropes end hath driuen me into a busines, here, deserues a whole Rope. But I hope that Destiny attends not me, though this Mariage be his: And since it is his Fate, faire befall it him, I am discharg'd

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come Gouernour, we are agreed lets goe that wee may hye vs againe, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay sir. You shall not say, you married me for nought: you shall heare me sing before you goe.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: What an Owsell tis ● shee meanes hee shall marry her for a Song. Byrlady a competent Moderne portion.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: As I was gathring Aprill's flowers,
He● streight let fall one of his showers;
Which draue me to an arbour.
Twere better I my Lap had fill'd.
Although the wet my clothes had spill'd,
Then to ha' found that harbour
For there a subtile Serpent was,
Close lying, lurking in the Grasse.
And there while harmelesse thinking I,
Still watching when the showre would dye,
Lay listning to a Bird,
That singing sate vpon the Bower,
Her noates vnto the falling showre,
the Snake beneath me stird;
And with his sting gaue me a clap,
that swole my belly not my lap.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my troth tis pretty.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: And by my conscience tis true, twere made i' Durham, on a Lasse of my bignesse.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: And in thy clothes I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: But will you be gan now, than all my ioy leaues me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sweet soule, thou shalt haue thy ioy againe. I will ioy thee, enioy thee, and ouer ioy thee. Gouernour let vs fly about this busines. I will not sleepe, before I haue got a License, stolne her away, wedded her, bedded her, and put her in her wits againe.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Are you able to doe that thinke you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile warrant thee: for all Maids are mad till they bee maried.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: What say you to that Lady. Pox on you, I runs sweet hazard to aduance your fortune, doe I not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Remember your Couenant with Master Tridewell Captaine. And when the worke is done, here's my hand, you shall partake of what I get by't. And harke you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Shee may perhaps, when shee comes to her selfe, and finds me to be no sir Phillip, be a litle startled. But I meane the first night to put so much of my owne loue into her, as shall worke out his I doubt not, or any his that came there before mee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O Gentlemen! my Masters comming, alls spoild if hee take you. Part quickly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Is mine Vncle comd? and mun we part than?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Kisse, and part; kisse and part.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Sweet heart, not a word of mee till I come to fetch you off with honour.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: All benisons bee with you. Indeed you be the goodliest man, that ere made Maiden faine.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Poore heart shee dotes. I doe not know how much I am in debt to my conscience, till I haue made her amends.—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: This may breed good blood. If I come but as well off o' my old Vncle, as am like to come on with my young Cosen, here will be a match vnlook'd for; a match without treaty; a match vntalk'd or vnheard of. Hee is comming before I haue shifted my face. Mee thinks I heare the rusting of his bristles hither. Yet my lips must stand the assault; pray loue the Porcupine, leaue none of his quills in 'hem.

div.head: Act. IIII. Sce. V.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where's my Girle? My hony sweet Girle? Kisse mee; Kisse I say directly: I'le secure thee. As I am a Man of Authority, and that of Midlesex, I'le secure thee. Ha my Lasse, these lips haue the true Elixir in 'hem indeede, to restore youth and strength; past all Medeas charmes, or what the Poets would haue fained. How now 〈…〉 Loue? I hope my Neeces habit has not wrought her disease into thee.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: No: now I see you sir, I am well: perfectly well: yet pardon me sir. Your absence cannot but breed me feare, when I haue leasure to thinke on my vnworthy condition, and the danger I vndergoe in't.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: 'Twas a thousand pitties that this Wench was seduc'd. Shee might haue made a Wife for a good Esquire. Shee would serue a Tradesman yet, most vnblemishably. And when I haue done with her, doing that for her, as I meane to doe. She may perhaps match with a younger brother, purchase him a place, aduance his fortune, to bee able in the end to repay she with a Ladiship. 'Tis not without a president; and I will help her to follow the example directly. For what I haue is mine owne, and I will be merry with it. Ha my bird, my chick ● Kisse me. Kisse me vp. So. Kisse me vp I say. So againe. Thou hast don't directly. Maintaine it now, with a cordiall kisse. So, so, so▪ Good. Very good; and while it is so, a word with you in priuate. Come my bird, mh mh mh.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sit, there's a woman below.—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir, what haue I to doe with any woman below: Doe you with your woman below, I am very well here.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Is the olde man mad trow. Sir, shee will haue to doe with you aboue, if you speak not with her below. I had much a doe to keepe her downe stayres, her case is so lamentable she sayes. I neuer saw a woman so importunate in my life sir. You must downe sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am downe already. All's naught. What limb of the devill is 't? Do'st thou know her?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee sayes shee is wife to a Constable sir, that you lately committed; and if your Wor. dos not release him presently, that hee's vndone, and shee's vndone, all their children are vndone, that vnborne in her belly is vndone, and I know not how many more are vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hell take her. How could she know that I was here?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee spied you in the Streete sir, and followed you, and follow you shee would, had you gone into the Priuy Chamber she sweares; her cause enforces her she sayes. And shee is so great with childe too, that no man dares giue her a thrust to keepe her back. I heare her blow vp stayres.

sp.speaker: Son
sp.p: Keepe her downe, I'le follow thee—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Good sir be pittifull for the womans sake, and release him. Perhaps her reckoning is out, and she has no body to call the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I must home to my Clearke then: for I cannot write here; nor do any good besides I am so vex'd. But I will returne to thee in the evening, Duck: And since I am so apt to be spied, ● will come disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Indeed I'le put out the Candle when you are here then, for I shall never endure to see other shape of Man. O these trunke ho●● are a comely wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be disguis'd directly. I will runne through all the shapes of Iupiter, before I will againe be prevented. Farewell. O my sweet! At seuen in the euening expect me.—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Sweet sayst thou? Thou art not I'le sweare. I am glad he was prevented. I should never held out a course with him, that cannot endure a breathing: a Cheese-shop on fire cannot out-stinke him.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Your Vncle's gone Mistris, and sayes hee will be here at seuen a clock againe. But shall I tell you a fiue thing Mistris?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yea marry Humfrey, what may that be and tis not of Sir Phillip

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But it is of him Mistris. Hee sayes hee will bring a Coach for your at sixe a clock to fetch you away: will you goe with him?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: By my saule that will I an't be all the world over.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: How shall you Vncle finde you at 7 then?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Wee'll leaue him at six and seauens. I meane betwixt both. 'Twill be trim trust me. And hear'st thou me Humfrey. Thou must bid Mistris Traynwell sonne to me a little before six ● for a very good reason.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hmh—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, it shall hinder nothing. Wee'le away the faster.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I thinke she be in her wits already. If not, I must humour her, though I bee put to the trouble to shift her away againe. Shee shall marre no sport that's certaine.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Come with me Humfrey, thou shalt goe eene now, and tell her; and I'le be packing vp the while.—

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: This Clinches. I shall winne my Ladies heart for euer. To mannage two such businesses more, were enough to raise me Agent for a State.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: Act. V. Scene I.
div.stage: Pate in a Doctors habit. Traynwell, Constance.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To discourse a tedious Lecture vnto you, Lady, in speaking philosophically of the disease of Melancholly, were to shew more learning then discretion. There are large volumes of it in Print, to very slender purpose.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I desire rather your discretion, then the glosse of Learning. I am rather govern'd by the wholsome effects of the one, then the smooth directions of the other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: To the point then Lady. I see no reason why I should vexe and torment this delicate and tender body, with Physick. Her disease is Melancholly; The cause of this disease I haue found apparantly in the two houres probation since you left her with me, to be Loue, which shee hath so greedily taken in, that it hath overwhelm'd her spirits, and turn'd the faculties of all her senses into a rude confusion, sending forth the vse of them extravagantly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I must not onely approue, but applaud your skill. Tis loue indeed, And ● am right glad that your opinion iumps with my owne knowledge: for now I doubt not of your speedy addresse to the cure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: 'Tis done in three words. The Party that shee loues, must be the Doctor, the Medicine, and the Cure.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentleman is below, he came with me, onely I would not bring him to her fight without your approbation, scaring it might doe hurt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Pray call him vp, on perill of my judgement. Ex. Tray .Giue me your hand Mrs. Constance. I haue good newes for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tis a long whayle ●ine I hear● ony.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Gentleman, whom you loue best, shall be your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He is wed already Sir. Another wife would gar him be put downe at gallowes: an ● I would not bee shee for all the wordly good that ere I saw with 〈…〉. And o' my conscience Ile be none of his 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She prattles very prettily me thinks. Married already? Sure Cupid shot you with a forked arrow out of his Crosbow. But what will you say Lady, if by my Ar● I render this Gentleman vnmarried againe, and a Suter vnto you presently?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry▪ shall I tell you what I'le say sir? That deserues hanging worse then tother matter, you would poyson his wife by your Art, wod yee? and make your gowne there the Hangmans ●ee the second time? It lookes as it had beene once his already; and you like such a Doctor I must tell yee, by your leaue. God blesse me fro thee. Mrs. Traynwell where are you?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Out of her wits say they? I feare shee is wiser then all of vs, that haue to doe with her. Shee knowes my gowne better than I doe: for I haue had but two houres acquaintance with it. 'Tis no longer since I hir'd it of the hangmans Merchant a Broker. It might ha' beene Lopus gowne for ought I know.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. II.
div.stage: Enter Traynwell and Lucklesse to them.

sp.speaker: Tray.
sp.p: They are falne out I thinke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
O Mrs. Traynwell, for deare Charities sake ha' me soone
fro' this Man: for I'le nere take ony thing at him. Hee talkes of poysoning.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By my faith you wrong me: Nor of any poysoning purpose. I was but putting a case of—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray put vp your Pipes sir. I like not your Musicke: troth nor his countenance nather. Sweet Mrs. Traynwell gar me be shut on him. Now all the joyes of Immortality light o' yee sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is that the Gent?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir. Pray obserue. But how fell you out sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I must first salute him by your favour. Sir, all the accumulations of honour showre downe vpon you.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: Sir. May you reape the whole harvest of your fruitfull wishes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Deare sir, keepe further fro' him.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: But one word sweet Lady; and you shall haue the whole benefit of his presence to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Be not afraid sweet-heart, he dares not hurt sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: In troth he breathes to neare him.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: Ile warrant you. What has hee done to moue her thus? I know not what this obscure Doctor is. But M. Tridewell put me vpon him; and his approved honesty has and must kill all m●s trust in me.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Your Coach is ready at dore you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ye● my most delicate Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: As you finde her then after a few words away with her. I haue perform'd my part sir. I'le hold the discreet gouernesse in talke in the next roome.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: But one word call yee this?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: I ha' done sweet soule. Lady I haue instructed the gent. shall we leaue them?

sp.speaker: Try
sp.p:
One word, by your leaue first M. Doctor, and I'le attend you. Sir not alone my Discretion, but my Reputation lies at stake: and I make no doubt of your noblenesse vpon your Kinsmans word, my Complotter in this busines. Therefore while I hold argument with the Doctor (who shal by no meanes perceiue our deceit) slip you away with her in your Coach, where M. Tridewell▪ hath appointed, till the Euening; and let me alone to scuffle with the old man the while▪ And then I doubt
not all our troblesome labours shall haue a peaceable end. Ile send old Mad-cap to your Lady in a Thunder-clap. But noble sir, your reputation—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My life and honour be her Guard, and your security.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No more sir. Ile lay no coniurations vpon so noble a spirit. Come Master Doctor—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But doe you loue me Constance?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O right weell sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And will you be my Woman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I is sure, ile nener be mine owne else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you will not goe away with mee now, if I request you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Any whither but to bed before wee be married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What from your Gouernesse, your Vncle, and all the World?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thanke you too sir. And ta' mee but fro' this ill looking Doctor; for I shall be weell with you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, since you trust me so well, wee two will not part till wee are lawfully made one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Heauen blisse the houre you speake in, and all Saints be witnesses.

div.head: Act. V. Sce. III.
div.stage: Enter Squelch, meeting Trainewell, and Pate.

sp.speaker: Squ
sp.p: Where's this Doctor? where's this melancholly Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O me is hee come?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is this her Vncle?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Euen he sir. Where's my charge; Mistris Constance?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Saue yee sir Ile goe find her—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where's my charge? Ile goe find her! What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee was here but now sir, while the Musick plaid. And wee withdrew our sclues, thinking she might sleepe sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There went a Coach away as I came in. Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A Coach sir? Alas I am affraid; my flesh trembles.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: At what in your great Master the Diuels name? Where's my Neece?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir here came in one Master Widgine, the Lady Luckles brother—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: As acquainted with the Doctor sir—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And he saw her sir. But seem'd to depart, when wee withdrew our selues to talke about the cure.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very very well. While you were wisely talking about the cure, a Widgine flies away with the Patient. Where's this Doctor? Doctor I say. Doctor! Hee's run away too, my life on't. A meere plot, a Conspiracie; tis so directly, below there. I can not see how it can bee otherwise. Ent. Cleark .Saw you the Doctor? Yes sir, hee went now forth at the water-Gate, and tooke boat in hast.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Exceeding well▪ How came your Discretion acquainted with this Doctor?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir he was reported to me by very good Iudgements, to be a rare Practitioner.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A most rare fellow, and do's admirable tricks, by slight of heeles. But I may perhaps out-run 'hem—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: My purge workes as I wisht. I am amus'd though at the flight of the Doctor. But I haue too many businesses to intertaine new thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: May I beleeue it, Good sir? may I be so happy, that my brother has her?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As I haue truth in me, I am most credibly told so. Mary the worst is, her Vncle is so mad at their escape, that hee will neuer giue consent to the match, whereby her portion will bee lesse.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hang him Clod. My will shall be a portion sufficient to my brother, I care not, though hee giue her not a penny, so Wat has the Wench.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Make you noe more doubt of that, then I doe Madame, who haue vpon the report of it already, prepard the Learned of the Ciuill Law, those that you nominated of your good acquaintance, and are forward to doe you the best office,
who haue appointed to meet before the IUdge of the Archdeacons Court presently, whither I haue promised to bring, and will attend you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But the other side must be summond by processe.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir Phillip hath warning already Madame; and without needlesse processe will bee there before you, and wait your comming. So that my selfe and his seruant, who haue neuer beene both absent from one of your companies, since your Mariage, iustly deposing you neuer did the reallest Rite of Mariage, the bed office, Madame; you both consenting, and desiring a Diuorce, It is instantly graunted, without any proceedings in Law. So that all will be ended in three whispers. Ods pitty, looke who here is.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O are you here my Lady Lucklesse?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Twas time you found me sir; you might ha' mistaken my name else. For within this heure, I might haue return'd the ancient title of your friend, and Awdery Fitchow.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Slow wov, where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Where are your wits sir? you come vpon me indeed ● What Neece? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: My Neece Constance, that your brother Widgine stole from the Doctor, and is stowne away withal. But hee must not thinke to scape so? I may take him, and his Duck too, in my Decoy, before they be coupled, as sure as your Ladiship or your Fitchow ship, and they thinke your selues.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sure the old Gentleman is fallen mad. What hath happend?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: The plot smels of your Ladiships policy; your Ladiships Lilly white fist is foule in the busines. But I will haue a bout at fisticuffs in Law with your Ladyship: your great acquaintance, and alliance in the Whatshical. Court No●●b●● 〈◊〉 your power there must not cary it, my great Lady. Directly it must not.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Your ●re an vnciuill greasie Companion, to vpbraid and reuile me thus in my owne house.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O good Madame, hurt not your selfe with anger better laugh it out.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hee makes me forget my selfe by his example. Sir you are a Commissioner for the Peace I take it. Do's it become a Man of your place and grauity, to fly out in these extreames? You spend too much breath in these lowd noates, very hurtfull to the Lungs, If you will fall into a lower Key, and speake peaceably, I will answere you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray you, Forsooth, or sweet Madame, or what you please; Where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Will you beleeue mee sir? you may: For tis Truth, as I haue any; And before this worthy Gentleman; I neuer saw your Neece in my life; only I haue heard shee is a pretty Gentlewoman: likely to make a good Match, for which I told my brother of her, and would haue treated with you for her, could I haue spoken with you as I wish'd by two or three Messages. But whither my brother has got her, or wher hee, or shee is of my owne knowledge, I cannot say directly.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Shee mocks me to my face all this while. Well good-Wife, Mistris, Madame—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well my Lord Innekeepers second Sonne: Do's your Provender prick you?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Prick Madame: I tell thee thou Thing, made vp of Chippings, broken Beare, Candle-ends, and sisting of Sea cole.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: out you Curry-combe.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Forbeare sweet Lady, let him be mad by himselfe.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be so reueng'd—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: How pray?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hee had beene better to haue kild a Man, rauish'd ● Virgiue; nay, done the most dangerous contempt that law could deuise to punish, then if I take him to suffer vnder my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Ile muster vp my Constables, and send out a priuy search immediately.—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What thinke you of your Brothers successe, now Madame?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Much the better, that it vexes him so: Sciruy foule unouth'd fellow.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Looke you now Madame. See who here comes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister fall downe, and adore me for my great atchieuement. Humfrey kneele downe to her that shee may dub thee for thy seruice. Neuer did the best nos'd Dogs, that euer were coach'd for their goodnesse, hunt more truely, take more brauely, and cary away more cleanely, then we haue done this dainty peece of flesh here. Sister kisse her, and be better acquainted: shee is mine owne flesh, Ile vphold it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Shee is a Holdup her selfe, if I mistake not her name.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Being your flesh brother, her nearest affinity of blood runs in my veines. Therefore with a sisters loue I embrace you, and bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Mine Vncle will by right wood I feare me. But Ile neare greet for that sir, while I haue your loue.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I know it is shee by her tongue, though I neuer heard her before. Nor euer feare sweet sister, wee shall be all frends shortly.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: I would be glad and twere so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister come hether. Now heare and admire my wit; as well as my Fortune. Humfrey come and take thy share of my sisters wonder.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I hope I perform'd my duty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which wee must not see vnrewarded sister.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No: I meane to giue him my Maid, and a hundred Marks with her, besides all shee has about her.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I am made for euer. I thanke your languishing Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well said Howdee: for my Ladiship is eene at the last gaspe. I am to bee Diuorc'd within this halfe houre. But your proceedings brother? How did shee receiue you at first?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O at first, shee was the prettiliest mad that ere you saw. You your selfe can not deuise to be so mad, as shee was.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
And all for sir Phillip, shee would loue none but sir Phillip, speake to none but sir Phillip. I told her I was sir Phillip,
(ah God a mercy Humfrey: that was thy inuention.) Then the litle Viper hang vpon me, not to be shak'd off, til I promis'd her Mariage, and to father a Child, which, in her distraction, shee conceited shee had by me. I promis'd her any thing; so tooke her into an inner too me, to make all sure, as well within as without; and I so phillipt her—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough brother, no more. I vnderstand you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But I must haue more, and shall neuer haue enough on't. It passeth your vnderstanding and mine too, the delight of it. [Sing ]Oh what a delight shee gaue me. And how light I am after 〈◊〉 Heigh. My pretty sweet Rascall.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough I say.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You doe not loue to heare on't, because you lack it. But you shall heare the Miracle it wrought sister. The losse of her Mayden head recouerd her wits. I made her right and streight in an instant. And now shee loues me in my owne person; knowes me for a Widgine, and will not giue her Wat for the best sir Philip of them all. And longs for nothing but the Priest and Bed time. Ha my sweeter and sweeter I My Gouernour's gone for a Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: So, ha you done now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile vndertake—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Yet againe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That Humfrey, and I with the tricks and trinkets, wee haue about vs will cure all the mad Maids of her standing in the Towne. And doe not thinke, but much may be gotten to professe it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You haue made a large relation Master Widgine, and a pleasant, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh I could liue and dye in this discourse sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady doe you thinke of the time?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I will instantly along with you. Hewdee come you with me. Brother, the search hath past this house already. You any goe in with your Sweet-heart, and stay here safely. Goe in, and keepe close, till I send to meet me at Supper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In and in sister, and be close enough, feare not—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Now sir when you please.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am your seruent Lady—

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistris, I will goe no further in this businesse, then you haue limited me in your directions: 'twill be revenge enough for my disgrace to make him see his error.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Therefore be discreet and secret. The disguise hee is in I haue told you. The place is this. At the dore you shall leaue me. The houre 7 a clock.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistris, I will not watch more truly at Midnight, then I will pray for you for this Discouery. I will instantly call my priuy-search, guard, and catch a bird, of Iustice in the lime-twigs of his owne Warrant.—

div.head: Act. V. Scene IX.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: I tit not speak with Sir Paule then, it seemes, to know the reason why I am subdoodled thus, In I protest and vow a kind of fooles Paradise.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Good sir beare your iniury with a Mans patience. Sir Paule will not be long absent. And till hee comes, my Mistris entreates you (for your owne good) to take his part vpon you, in giving entertainment to divers of his friends, who are invited hither to a Feast to night.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: H● you any Whitpots?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Much better meat sir. But here's the strangenesse of it; and the onely occasion that requires you ayde in the entertainment. This great Supper or feast (as I may properly call it) was appointed by Sir Poule himselfe, the money to buy the Provisioned deliver'd by his owne hand, to his own Servant; the Guests of his owne election; vet he, out of the multiplicity of crosse effaires, that haue happ'ned this day, hath quite forgot that there was any such preparation, or any such meeting intended, as appeares evidently by his absence. But my Mistris has got all the meate privately made ready at the next house, on purpose that he should should see nothing—

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: To try is he would forget it or no?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Right sir. I haue bidden all the Guests: and expect them immediatly.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But what must I say to 'hem?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Onely salute 'hem, bid 'hem welcome; Tell'hem Sir Paule was hastily call'd forth on his Majesties affaires; Entreat their patience till his returne, which you know will be every sodaine although you know not where he is; and so forth, as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Your Master abroad and not within say you?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Yes. But good sir stay his comming, I pray you, for his good.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I partly apprehend you at full. Mistris Traynwell appointed me to come too with all possible speede. M. Nonsense you are well apprehended.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Onely salute 'hem, bid 'hem welcome. Tell'hem Sir Paule was hastily call'd forth on his Maiesties affaires. Entreat their patience till his returne, which you know will bee very sodaine, although you know not where he is. And so forth as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Loue has made you a Courtier. M Nonsense

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No I protest and vow. I doe but speake as they say.—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What haue you said Sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: What you said I haue an ill verbatim else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I said but the meaning of what you should say, and put it in your owne words.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No sir. I will take your owne words for this matter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I am beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: I am glad Fortune has sent one man of Civill government before the Roarers come. Here comes some of 'hem already. I'le downe and looke to the rest of the house.

div.stage: Enter Lucklesse, Constance, disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Saue you sir. Are you the Worshipfull of the house?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you sir.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir?—

sp.speaker: Bul.
