sp.p: Mistake me not I beseech you, I apprehend you to be some great stranger here: because you know the place better then the Master of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You doe not mock me sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, This is one of the Guests?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Onely salute 'hem. Bid 'hem welcome—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Tell 'hem Sir Paule was hastily call'd forth on his Maiesties affaires—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is this a Parrat or a Popingay?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Entreat their patience till his return, which you know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe you know what you say sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Will be very sodaine, although you know not where hee is—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I did I would not seeke him here sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: And so forth as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is some inchaunted Place, and the people are charm'd. I haue mistaken the house sure.

div.stage: Enter Tridewell and Fitchew disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Where's this hospitable Knight that invites Strangers. I meane meere Strangers, that hee knowes not. Shew me the Lad of bounty. I hunger not for his Sapper as I doe to salute him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hee will proue the greatest stranger here himselfe I thinke, for he is not at home sir. I am a Guest as you are, and would be as glad to see him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He dos not meane to ieare vs dos he?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I beseech you mistake not so his purpose sir: which is faire welcome, and good cheare to you all. Therefore Gentlemen and ladies, will it please you to entertaine one another a while. [Enter Cleark with Sack and Tobacco. ]Look yee. Here's good Sack, and good Tobacco. And before the rest of the Guests become, Sir Paule will be here himselfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellow speakes.

div.stage: Enter Anv. widg. Holdup. and Howdoe disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As I am a Iustice of Peace I cannot apprehend, and yet me thinks I doe. What sort of people these Gentlemen may be. See: more I Is sir Paule turn'd swaggerer? Or is his house abus'd by servants? I will not leaue it, vntill they goe out before mee like a layle deliuery. They looke like men betwixt a Repriue and Pardon. Friend: Are these sir Paules elected friends?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: His protected friends sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Protected?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
I sir. There is a fraternity of them. The brothers of
the Protect. There's not a man of 'hem, but has all Mayors, Sheriffes, Bayliffes, Sergeants at Mace, Marshalls men, Constables, and other his Maiesties Officers, in a Combcase in his pocket. They are a Generation that never eate but in Parliament time, and now every table is full of them.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I should wonder what they did here else. See. A roaring Doctor too, broke out o' the Kings Bench.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By your leaue Gallants. I perceiue your Company is not yet full.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Are you of the invited sir?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: It is not to be doubted sir. Yet a Voluntary. But there are some without that are more then invited, yet come against their wills.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How meane you M. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Brought sir by a Constable and Officers, to be examin'd. Where's the iolly Iustice?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What are they can yee tell sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, and a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A Spaniard, Ha!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I, a Spaniard, Ha: if you will haue it so:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If we had but a Iustice among vs to Examine 'hem, it might passe the time well till sir Paule came.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Iustice, and for the same purpose too for ought we know, that shall not refuse to doe it, and in sir Paules Gowne and Cap too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a witty fellow.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, you cannot doe a more acceptable office for your friend, then to execute his place in his absence. Your authority makes you capable of it; and I doe the rather perswade it, because the Gentlemen whom you wisely suspect for loose persons, may see some example of Iustice; which may preuent some present euill in their stay here.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you friend. Giue mee the Gowne and Chayre, and let the Delinquents approach. Vmh, vmh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Tis a Spaniard indeede.

div.stage: Enter Vexhem, Squelch, like a Spaniard, Trayn. Cleark.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p:
An English Spaniard sir, And therefore the verier
knaue: as will bee prou'd I doubt not, to his shame, and my renowne in the Common wealth. By your Worships leaue.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What newes bring you M. Constable?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Spanish newes sir. Wilt please your Worship to examine the vertue of my Warrant, and then these Persons accordingly?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very good! I am brought before my selfe to bee examin'd, and before a fine rable too! how the deuill brok this vnknowne Nation into my house, or doe not I mistake it? My foolery has led me into a fine predicament. I will not yet disclose my selfe: but looke a little further towards the event.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Are you a Spaniard sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Such a one as you see Signior.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: See Signior. Hee speakes nothing but Spanish. The question will be how we shall vnderstand this Examinant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I do see Signior I thanke the light, that you are a goodly man of outward parts, and ezcept it were the black Knight himselfe, or him with the Fistula, the proprest man I haue seene of your Nation. They are a People of very spare dyet, I haue heard, and therefore seldome fat. Sure you you haue had most of your breeding in this Countrey, the dyet whereof you like better then your own, which makes you linger here, after all you Country men, vpon some vncouth plot. And I shall wonder therefore how you can speake no English. Can you speake no English at all sir? Answere me I pray.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not an English word not I s●●. Alasse I haue not been fiue ●ayes in the Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is excellent!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I, You'll marre all if you laugh.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Alasse, what shall wee doe then? Gentlemen, haue any of you any Spanish, to helpe mee to vnderstand this strange Stranger?

sp.speaker: Thi
sp.p: Not a Riall sir not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor a Rialls worth amongst vs of any language but shiere English.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What Shiere of our Nation is next to Spaine? Perhaps he may vnderstand that Shier, English.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Deuonshire or Cornwall sir.

sp.speaker: Non
sp.p: Neuer credit me, but I will spowt some Cornish at him. Peden bras vidne whee his cregas.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Am I transform'd vtterly? Is my Language alter'd with my apparell, or are you all mad? what vnspeakeable misery is this.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I see we shall neuer vnderstand, nor doe good on him, till hee be instructed in the English tongue.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: And please your worship, the best Vniuersity for this purpose will be Bridewell. I am acquainted with the best Tutors there, Master Cleanewhip, Master Dri-lash, and diuers others.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You officious Rascall, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: No such matter sir. But in my right mind, and Midlesex feare it not.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: It must be so. His instruction will cost litle there, if hee be not too old to learne. Therefore set him by, and let mee fall vpon the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Oh, hee's rarely vext.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Now Gentlewoman, will it please you to be vnmasqu'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir looke you, I dare shew my face.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Mistris Trainowell, as I apprehend.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mistris Trainewell.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Trainewell!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Euen shee Gentlemen, as I will more circumstantially reueale vnto you presently, after a word or two with my fellow prisoner, for which I craue your fauour.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: With all my heart, so you can speake Spanish and make him vnderstand you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You see I am not the Woman you tooke me for: but one ordain'd for your greater good. If you will giue me my present demand. I will turne all your disgrace into laughter; make you of worthier esteeme now at the instant, then euer you were, by the generall approbation of these, and all that know you beside. Your Neece to shall be restor'd to your owne liking, and all shall be as well as you can wish. Otherwise, if you haue a mind to bee euerlastingly sham'd, by being perpetually laught at, take your owne course, Ile take mine.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am astonish'd. What is your Demaund?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Whereas your purpose was to make a Whore. Make me your honest Wife; no more. Bee sodaine in your resolue, all will be naught else.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I am in a mischieuous streight then. Redime to captum. Thy wit deserues my loue. Ile do't; here's my hand and faith, Ile
do't. Thou art mine, and I am thine directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Then hearke you sir.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Sir what will you say, if this Gentlewoman conuert the Spaniard, turne him true English subiect, and present him to you with the oaths of Alegiance, & Supremacie in his mouth presently?

sp.speaker: Bull
sp.p: I wil say, she deserues for euer hereafter to hold her peace.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Now beare vp sir. Looke confidently, and say, you put on your Disguise purposely to intertaine disguis'd Guests. Come auant with your Picca de goat, and beginne with the Iustice here.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou hast made me a Man for euer, and I will make thee a Woman directly. Gallants saue you. See here the Metamor.phosis, that meanes to metamorphose you all. Alas I know you for all your Disguises, and thought to intertaine you in your kind.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Sir Paul Squelch!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: First out of you, my Vsurper, and most Vpstartical Iustice, whose office is your trade, and Clearke your Prentice, I will draw a man of litle, or no Moment: yet my frend, and Master Bulfinch, out of the Chaire of Iustice. this my prognosticate the putting of my selfe, or many others out of Commission within these few yeares; though I am no Prophet. Doe I speake English now? Doe I know you now, or you me?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Question 〈◊〉, we should know one another sir Paul: or else one of vs two were both very ignorant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: To proceed in my Metamorphosis. I will change you most confus'd Roarer, into an accomplisht Knight. And bid you welcome, noble sir Phillip Lucklesse.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I like the change well, and thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Next sir of you Roarer, or Iieter, or whatsoeuer you are, I will make a compleat Gentleman, most answerable to you name Master Tridewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: But out of you Master Doctor, I will pick a certaine Knaue. Where is my Neece sirah?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Which of your Neeces sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Haue I so many sir? I meane my only one Constance, find her me, ●r I will translate you out of an Aesculapian Cocke into a Newgate Bird immediatly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir if you will Metamorphose me out of a Batchelor, into a Bridegroome, Ile shew you your Neece.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: This my Neece?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: O haue I found you Mistris? Sir this is the Gentlewoman I brought before your worship to day.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold they peace; art in thy right mind?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: As I am in my right mind and Midlesex, it is she sir. I had not matter enough then to lay to her charge; for which I thanke your worship I kist Newgate. But now I haue sir; she has left a Child vpon our Parish, I am sure got by an vnknowne father; and has beene a loose Liuer, both at Duke Humfreyes, and most of the winkd it houses about the Towne these foure yeares: which I can sufficiently proue.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Knaue. Ile put these plums i' thy mouth else

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, my Child shall trouble your Parish no longer, here is a Father, my troth plight Husband, sufficient to keepe it and me, wilt thou not Duck?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Duck? my name is Widgine, you mistake the man sure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sure I doe not. This Gentleman, and this Gentlewoman, and this trusty Seruant of ours are my witnesses, I am your Wife sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I am vndone, quite cast away. Sister helpe mee now with your Law wit, or I perish for euer.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This is not to bee endured: cheating, and vile abuse, This contract can not bee lawfull. One person mistaken for another a lawfull impediment to be diuorc'd for, though they were married.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It might doe well if (as hee confesses himselfe) he had not made all too sure, as well within as without.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir Phillip, while they wrangle out their cause, let vs agree: Find you but the meanes to make her lawfully your Wife, and here take her with my faithfull promise, of the equall halfe of any estate presently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I say this is no lawfull contract: And though we are legally diuorc'd, yet neither he nor I may lawfully marry, while we both liue, hauing beene lawfully married. And till you can disproue that, sir Ile forbid your Banes good sir Phillip, and lay your hopes a cooling, frendly Master Tridewell, for your loue in managing this businesse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady giue me leaue, if I haue strayn'd a point of friendship, it was your loue gaue the strenght to my wit. Fit. My loue?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your loue indeed Lady. Which (and which Cupid pardon me for) now, that I see I may enioy, I am not so eagerly taken with, yet if you will—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Sir you cannot enioy me, not he her, lesse you can disproue
the lawfulnesse of our former Mariage.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: To cleare that point, doe you know the Minister?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Tis not so long since, but I can remember his face.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Then to continue sir Pauls Metamorphosis? Ile draw him out of this Doctor. Is not this hee?

sp.speaker: Fit
sp.p: It is. But is not hee a lawfull Minister; I would know that.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To cleare that doubt there lyes my Order of Priesthood.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who, Oliuer!—

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Euen hee, the Parson Nochurch, and this my Patron, whom I must beseech together with the whole company, to preserue me out of the high Commission: for looke you, here is againe your Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Would you doe this Master Tridewell?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Faith I foresaw an vnto wardnesse in the Match: which if you repent the breach of, there's your Licence; and the way to Church lyes before you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No sir. First get my brother free of his contract, and then a Licence with your owne name, and Ile waite on you to Church, as soone as you will.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O that's done already. What are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Most happily sir, sister alls well againe. I haue giuen her a hundred pound to relinquish her right in me. Which afore all these witnesses you doe; doe you not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes most freely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well then, I will not forsweare to marry, But if euer I steale a Wife againe, let her be a witch, and may I burn with her for company. Gouernour, thou art out of countenance, and thou too honest Humfrey, me thinkes. Come beare vp. I forgiue. Twas your errors, not malice.

sp.speaker: How
sp.p: Sir for my part, ile take my corporall oath—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It shall not need good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And for me sir— wid. Nay, I dare not but beeleeue thee before thou speakest Gouernour: therefore prithee lets not talke on't our selues, but quietly, and presently beginne our trauels, that we may heare no body else talke on't.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, I see you all at peace so well, that I wish no further content to any, except Master Nonsense here.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: Neuer credit me but I haue had sport enough 'o conscience, and if I doe not make a Stage phyen't, when I come into Cornewall: I protest and vow then say there was Nonsense in this.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am glad you conclude so frendly with the rest. All the vnquietnesse will be in the Kitchin presently If your meat stay for you. Gallants. Knock Within I was time to speake. They knock at Dresser already. Will yee in?
sp.l: You are all Welcome: And I wish euery Guest
as merry, as our Northern Lasses Feast.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
